article.title: The KMOS Deep Survey (KDS) II: The evolution of the stellar-mass Tully-Fisher relation since z   4

multiple_choice_question.text: What does this figure illustrate about the KDS rotation-dominated galaxies compared to the local reference and KROSS star-forming galaxies?
choices: KDS rotation-dominated galaxies have higher rotation velocities at fixed stellar mass.
KDS rotation-dominated galaxies have lower rotation velocities at fixed stellar mass.
KDS rotation-dominated galaxies have similar rotation velocities at fixed stellar mass.
KDS rotation-dominated galaxies have a steeper slope in the rotation velocity vs. stellar mass relation.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the middle panel of this figure suggest about the evolution of the stellar-mass Tully-Fisher relation for rotation-dominated galaxies at z â‰¥ 1?
choices: The velocity zero-point is consistently offset to lower values compared to the local relation.
The velocity zero-point is consistently offset to higher values compared to the local relation.
There is a wide range of offsets, both positive and negative, with no clear trend.
The velocity zero-point offsets are all consistent with zero, indicating no evolution.

multiple_choice_question.text: What trend does this figure demonstrate regarding the connection between sample selection and observed stellar-mass Tully-Fisher evolution?
choices: Samples with stricter \'disky\' selection criteria (smaller normalized parent fraction) tend to show no evolution.
Samples representative of the evolving-disk population (larger normalized parent fraction) show larger offsets.
Samples with stricter \'disky\' selection criteria (smaller normalized parent fraction) show larger positive velocity offsets.
There is no clear correlation between sample selection and observed evolution.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the left panel of this figure illustrate about the virial mass of KDS isolated-field sample galaxies computed using only rotation velocities?
choices: The virial mass exceeds the stellar mass for most galaxies, including those in the rotation-dominated subsample.
The virial mass is consistently lower than the stellar mass for most galaxies, including those in the rotation-dominated subsample.
There is no clear difference in virial mass between rotation-dominated and dispersion-dominated galaxies.
The virial mass traces the stellar mass accurately for all KDS galaxies.
